vignette.presentation:
A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of severe shortness of breath. The patient says, "It feels like I'm
suffocating." He has hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. His medications are aspirin, clopidogre l, atorvastatin, and metoprolol.
On arrival, he is in severe respiratory distress and uses accessory muscles of respiration. He is only able to speak in short sentences. His temperature is
37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 123/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 245/113 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 15 L/min of oxygen by nonrebreather face
mask shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. Auscultation of the lungs discloses crackles to the apex bilaterally. Heart sounds are normal. Trace periphera l
edema is noted. An ECG is shown. The most appropriate next step is administration of which of the following?

question_stem: The most appropriate next step is administration of which of the following?

vignette.presentation:
A 57-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of nasal congestion and sneezing, a 5-hour history of fever, shaking chills,
and cough, and a 2-hour history of right-sided pleuritic chest pain. Sixteen months ago, he was diagnosed with multiple myeloma. His only medication is
prednisone for hypercalcemia. He is in obvious respiratory distress . His temperature is 40.2°C (104.4 °F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood
pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. There is dullness to percussion at both lung bases, increased tactile fremitus, and bronchial breathing. Tenderness is noted over
the left mid humerus. His hematocrit is 30%, and leukocyte count is 24,000/mim3 (24 x 109/L). An x-ray of the chest is consistent with bilateral lower lobe
pneumonia. A Gram stain of the sputum shows many segmented neutrophils, a few bronchial epithelial cells, and a moderate number of extracel lular gram
positive diplococci. This patient most likely has which of the following types of pneumonia?

question_stem: This patient most likely has which of the following types of pneumonia?

A 4 ?-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after a can of gasoline exploded 5 feet from him at a construction site. Since that time, he
has had pain and loss of hearing in his right ear. On arrival, he is in mild distress . His temperature is 37.1 °C (98.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min,
and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Examination shows abrasions over the right side of the face, neck, and upper chest. There is blood in the external
auditory canal of the right ear and swelling and ecchymosis of the right pinna. He cannot hear whispered voices in his right ear. Examination of the left ear
shows no abnorma lities. Which of the following is the most likely explanat ion for this patient's right ear symptoms?

vignette.presentation:
A 73-year-old woman who resides in a skilled nursing care facility is brought to the emergency department after she was found lethargic and minimally
responsive 30 minutes ago. She has had a 3-day history of vomiting and has not produced urine during the past 24 hours. She was hospitalized for
pneumonia 3 weeks ago. She has renal insufficiency, type 2 diabetes mellitus, congestive heart failure, and dementia. Her medications are furosemide,
metformin, and memantine. She has no known allergies. On arrival, the patient moans incoherently to questions or stimulation. Her temperature is 35.4 °C
(95. 7°F), pulse is 82/min and regular, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 90/43 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of
93%. The skin is cool and clammy to touch. Crackles are heard at the lung bases. The abdomen is soft; there is mild, diffuse tenderness to palpation. There is
moderate pitting edema of the lower extremities. She is able to move all four extremities, but she does not cooperate with a neurologic examination.
Fingerstick blood glucose concentrat ion is 78 mg/dl (4.33 mmol/L). An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

question_stem: Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

vignette.presentation:
A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a friend because of a 2-hour history of progress ive headache, confusion, nausea, and
dizziness. He and his friend had been fishing on a small boat when the patient's symptoms began. The patient had been operating the outboard motor
continuously for the latter part of the day. He and three other boating parties joined together for lunch with the boats tethered together at midlake. He had
caught several fish and consumed a packed lunch of tuna sandwiches and beer. He has a history of hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide and low
back pain treated with oxycodone with acetaminophen as needed. He appears confused and is oriented to person but not to place or time. Vital signs are
within normal limits. Examination shows no abnorma lities. Results of complete blood count and metabolic panel are within the reference ranges. Which of the
following is the most appropriate treatment?

Which of the
following is the most appropriate treatment?

vignette.presentation:
A 4 ?-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a friend 30 minutes after a seizure. The friend says that while they were sitting on the couch at
home, the patient suddenly became quiet, arched his back, and began to shake. The episode lasted 45 seconds. Immediately afterward, the patient was
confused for 15 minutes. He has hypertens ion treated with amlodipine. He has no known drug allergies. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20
years. He drinks eight to nine beers nightly. His last drink was 28 hours ago. On arrival, he is sleepy but responds to verbal stimuli. He appears restless. His
temperature is 38.1 °C (100.6°F), pulse is 106/min and regular, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 148/92 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air
shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Physical examination shows clammy skin. The remainder of the examination, including neurologic examination, shows no
abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

vignette.presentation:
A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of
severe left upper back pain. The pain began suddenly while he was golfing; he thought he may
have pulled a muscle during his swing but is surprised by the degree of pain. He rates the pain
as a 10 on a 10-point scale. It does not vary with deep breaths, exertion, movements of his
arms, or rotation of his trunk. He is concerned that he might be having a heart attack because
his 52-year-old brother just had a myocardial infarction. The patient has hypertension treated
with hydrochlorothiazide. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 29 years. On arrival,
the patient is diaphoretic and in moderate distress. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is
110/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 180/90 mm Hg. Pulse
oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Jugular venous distention is noted.
Auscultation of the lungs discloses bilateral crackles. Cardiac examination discloses a diastolic
low-pitched murmur best heard at the upper right sternal border. Abdominal examination shows
no abnormalities. There is no peripheral edema. A chest x-ray and ECG are shown. Which of the
following is the most appropriate next step in management?
O
A) Administration of aspirin, nitroglycerin, and morphine

vignette.presentation:
A 62-year-old man with chronic low back pain comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of feeling light-headed. He has not had chest
pain or palpitations. He says that he usually has constipation , but he has had bowel movements daily for the past 5 days. The stools are a dark reddish brown.
His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 140/min and regular, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. The patient is too light-headed to
check orthostatics. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft, nontender, and not distended. Rectal examination shows soft, dark red stool; test
of the stool for occult blood is positive. Fingerstick blood glucose concentrat ion is 92 mg/dL (5.11 mmol/L). Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8.0 g/dL (80 g/L)
Hematocrit 22%
Leukocyte count 8000/mm3(8 x 1Q 9/L)
Platelet count 240/mm3 (0.24 x 109/L)
Serum
Lactate 6 mg/dL (0.67 mmol/L) [N 5-15 mg/dL//0.55-1.65 mmol/L]
Coagulation studies are within normal limits. An ECG shows no abnorma lities other than sinus tachycardia. A blood sample is sent for typing and crossmatch
laboratory studies. A subclav ian catheter is inserted, and its position is confirmed by chest x-ray. After administration of 0.9% saline (2 L) through a large-bore
peripheral intravenous catheter, pulse is 120/min and regular, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Repeat serum lactate concentration is 4.5 mg/dL (0.5
mmol/L). Central venous pressure is 11 mm Hg (N 3-8). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

symptoms. His only medication is albuterol by metered-dose inhaler. He has been using his inhaler more frequently during the past 2 days with minimal relief
of symptoms. The patient has no known drug allergies. He appears to be in mild respiratory distress and uses accessory muscles of respiration. BMI is 23
kg/m2. His temperature is 38.1 °C (100.6°F), pulse is 106/min and regular, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 132/86 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on

ago, she underwent a sigmoidectomy for perforated diverticulitis. Her postoperative course has been otherwise uncomplicated. She has not had fever,
diarrhea, or pain with urination. Her last bowel movement yesterday was normal. She has not passed any flatus today. Her medications are ciprofloxacin,
metronidazole, and oxycodone-acetaminophen. On arrival, the patient is in moderate distress. She is awake and alert. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F),
pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 140/65 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%.
Cardiopulmonary exam ination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is moderately distended and diffusely tender to palpation in all four quadrants. The
surgical incision is clean, dry, and intact. Bowel sounds are decreased. An x-ray of the abdomen shows multiple loops of distended small bowel with air-fluid
levels throughout; no air is noted in the rectum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

vignette.presentation:
A previously healthy 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the sudden onset of dizziness, numbness, and neck pain.
She was participating in a vigorous aerobics class when she began to have sharp pain on the right side of her neck that spread to the back of her head,
followed by a sensation of spinning and left-sided numbness. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperatu re is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse
is 90/min and regular, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Examination shows mild narrowing of the right palpebral fissure. The right pupil is 2 mm, and the
left pupil is 4 mm; both pupils are reactive to light. Ocular movements are full. Funduscop ic examination shows no abnormalities. The palate does not elevate
on the right, and the tongue protrudes in the midline. Muscle strength is full. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ throughout. Babinski sign is absent. Sensation to
pinprick is decreased over the entire left side of the body and right side of the face. Sensation to vibration and proprioception are intact. There is an intention
tremor of the right upper extremity. Her gait is mildly ataxic. Her speech is mildly slurred. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

vignette.presentation:
A 77-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of confusion, lethargy, and excessive sleepiness over the past 3 weeks. Three days ago,
he fell and struck his head. On arrival, he has a generalized tonic-clonic seizure that lasts 40 seconds. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus and
has a history of frequent urinary tract infections and renal calculi. His medications include losartan, glyburide, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. He is
lethargic but easily aroused. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 190/105 mm Hg. Examination
shows an ecchymosis over the left scalp. Pupils are equally round and reactive to light. Doll's eye (oculocephalic) maneuver shows full eye movement.
Cranial nerves are intact. He moves all four extremities in response to painful stimuli. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the upper and lower extremities.
Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. There is an occasional myoclonic jerk in the lower extremities. He is disoriented to place and time. Laboratory studies

metastases to the skull, multiple vertebral bodies, ribs, liver, and para-aortic lymph nodes. Medications include tamoxifen, sustained-release morphine, stool
softeners, and fluoxetine. Her temperature is 36. ?°C (98.1 °F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. Examination
shows a large suprapubic mass. There is significant pain over the entire lumbar spine on fist percussion. Rectal examinat ion shows decreased sphincter
tone. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the incontinence?

vignette.presentation:
An otherwise healthy 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after an episode of loss of consciousness while shaving. Prior to
the episode, he had light-headed ness, nausea, and dimming of vision. His wife states that he was unconscious for about 1 minute and lost control of bladder
function. She did not notice any movement during the episode. He had a similar episode 1 month ago while shaving. At that time, echocardiography, 24-hour
ambulatory ECG monitoring, and a tilt test showed no abnormalities; cardiac enzyme activities were within the reference range. His current blood pressure is
